title: USB stick and iso image greater of 4096 MB

forumNotes.author: Balubeto Balubeto
forumNotes.content:
Hi

I would use the WinSetupFromUSB utility to create a USB stick to insert two customized iso of Windows 8.x.

The problem is that one of the image exceeds the size of 4096 MB.

So, how do I do to put this image in the USB stick so that, when I will have to boot from this USB stick into a BIOS or UEFI computer, its operating system starts correctly?

Thanks

Bye

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Are you saying that you tried it and it did not work (or just that you *think* it might not work)?

Is the \\sources\\install.wim over 4GB?

Did you read the FAQ on the WinSetupFromUSB site?

forumNotes.author: Balubeto Balubeto
forumNotes.content:
> Are you saying that you tried it and it did not work (or just that you *think* it might not work)?
>
> Is the \\sources\\install.wim over 4GB?
>
> Did you read the FAQ on the WinSetupFromUSB site?

The file install.wim is less than 4GB.  

On a VM of WorkStation, the ISO, inserted on a virtual DVD, it works correctly.  

If, instead, I run the iso from USB stick on a computer with the UEFI, the boot manager is displayed but when I try to start the operating system, it does not start; whereas with a computer with the BIOS, I have no problem. How come?

Thanks

Bye

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Why not test it using a VM that will UEFI boot from the USB drive - e,g, [VirtualBox + DavidB's Virtual Machine Boot USB utility](http://www.rmprepusb.com/tutorials/how-to-boot-from-usb-under-vmware-server#TOC-Boot-from-a-USB-drive-using-Oracle-VM-VirtualBox "External link")?

Check that the \\EFI\\boot\\bootx64.efi file is present and that the USB drive is FAT32.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
WInSetupFromUSB copies the entire ISO to the USB drive. You can always try Easy2Boot.

As long as the install.wim is below 4GB there should be no problem making a .imgPTN file.

If the instal.wim/esd is over 4GB then read [here](http://www.easy2boot.com/add-payload-files/adding-windows-install-isos-without-needing-a-helper-flash-drive/ "External link").

forumNotes.content: All info is on the site. There are two versions of E2B (one contains XP 32-bit drivers) - either will work.
